notes: Ku-ku is sometimes used as a greeting with small children.
The meaning of the word 'vatrogasci' is 'firefighters'; this might be a problem with the Croatian CDI. 'Vatrogasno vozilo' means 'firetruck'

Croatian children rarely use actual crayons (colored wax) for coloring. They use wooden coloring pencils which are called 'bojice''. Crayons are called 'pastele' but kids often call them 'pastelne bojice'. In croatian a universal concept for thing children color with would be 'bojica', but best english match is 'crayon'.

Children under 3 years of age use felt tip pens far less than coloring pencils. But when they do they use them for coloring so a universal concept for thing children color with (crayon) would be closer to the actual meaning for them than thing people write with (pen/pencil).
Both adults and children often call picture books (slikovnice) just books (knjige).
Other option would be snack.
Candy would be ok too.
Or just 'nuts'.
Or a spatula

Depending on context 'klupa' can be also a school desk but it is highly unlikely a 3 year-old child would use it like that. 'Klupa' (bench) would be the closest to the concept of a thing people usually sit on outside, but it is used to refer to 'stool (seat)' as well.
Or storage space.
There is show in the list of possible lemmas but it does not have a description. If it is a show (noun) than it can be used here.
Best I could find amongst the proposed lemmas is outside.
Or a farm.
Point of this game is to run after a child and catch him/her, which would conceptually be similar to the game of tag.
In the Bank 'wave' doesn't have a descriptive word but this is wave (action).
Since this word is a homograph of tear (from eyes) and tear (rip apart) I am not sure which one is in the Bank. Obviously, here it is an action word.
Belonging to one's self.
Since this is where morphology differs between languages I will choose the most prototypical form of the given words which are offered in the Bank.
Was' is not in the Bank.

new_uni_lemma: May is not a croatian word. It should be 'je' here which means '(he/she) is'.
